One thing that could be done is electric motors driving hydraulic pumps which directly drive hydraulic element (think of hydraulics as "reduction gearbox" for motor).  Hydraulics is good at concentrating a lot of force in a small place.  Just look at the common "bottle jack".  I have seen this done for ship's rudders (with the hydraulic output looking like a round hot-tub with a rotating and stationary divider).  There are no spool valves, reservoirs, and the like.  The motor's motion is directly transferred to the output, versus a backhoe, where a constantly-running engine pumps fluid which is valved to the cylinders.

All the domes will have plastic floors so no water is lost. Condensation forming on the ceilings will be drained into the water supply. All the domes will be blown up with compressed air from earth and will have a refresh system, which will refresh the air and maintain the air pressure. Humidity, Temperature will be maintained by humidifiers, heaters, fans and coolers. Light will be provided by multi-color LEDs, mostly white. The first colonist will be 5 fathers and 5 mothers, and 90 babies. The parents will be good parents, gardeners, farmers, zoo keepers, teachers, etc.. This plan will allow the kids to grow up in the isolation of the colony, and will make it easier for them to live in the isolation of the colony on the moon. Don't underestimate the compact nature of hydraulics. They can transmit enormous amounts of energy and force using very small components indeed. Typically, the IC or electrical motor driving a hydraulic pump is ~10 x the diameter and many times the length of the pump. Ditto the hydraulic motor. Go and take a close look at some earth moving equipment for an idea of scale.
As a random example, a 70 kW hydraulic motor capable of exerting a torque of 1480 Nm weighs 20 or 30 kg, depending on model from the same manufacturer. How much does an electric motor with an output of 70 kW weigh?

Now that I understand the philosophies behind the Spaceship, better, I think it takes certain elements of the space shuttle and combine them with elements of a rocket, more specifically, SpaceX's rockets.

I wouldn't be surprised if SpaceX uses electric motors. The only concern I have is the fundamental fact that electric motor's operating efficiency goes down big time as they get hotter. And these fin actuators are located between the two largest sources of heat: the tail rocket exhaust and the re-entry friction! Those actuators gonna need serious thermal protection to work correctly.

Personally, methinks it would make better sense to make the three tail fins ALL more or less fixed and put the operating control surfaces near the nose end. Another thing I would consider for the nose end is the possibility of using a third fin on dorsal side of nose end to serve as a heat radiator for the electric fin control motors more for thermal management.

Did you that the BUFF, B52 doesn't have ailerons! It only uses spoilers to control the wings up and down movement. Almost every airliner used today uses spoilers once landed to help slow down. Next time you fly set where you can see the top of the wings. You will see spoilers used a lot,  in flight and landing. Even small Cessna 152, 172, 182 many use the elevator once on the ground as a air break,  giving full up to give more drag, it also takes some load off the noise wheel. This is not the same but it is to a point. It you put some drag on the air going over the wing, it slows down the air,  when you slow down the air over the wing it gives less lift. When an airliner wants to get down faster they can put the spoilers up and the wings don't give as much lift and it goes down faster, not used all the wings only parts of it. I don't know much about the game you used but the right amount of drag added at the right places can make a lot of difference. Thank you for the information.  I am not saying that your information isn't good just adding some side information from someone that has a little to add.

One issue you're forgetting is that the greater the deceleration of the spacecraft during re-entry, the higher the negative g-forces will be. It's the force you feel when you apply the brakes in your car. So if the spacecraft has a really steep re-entry and massive deceleration as you described, the negative g-forces the passengers are going to experience will be brutal. It would be an extremely rough ride and a lot of people are going to pass out. SpaceX is going to have to take negative Gs into consideration and not make the re-entry TOO steep.

No silly. Hydraulics do NOT always operate slow, und can be extremely fast, giving ability for fine adjustment, und has much variance in (heat exchange/atmospheric pressure).
It ist a proven und logical option for manipulating flight control surfaces, und why it ist currently used in this way for modern high-speed aircraft...smiles However, electrical attenuated servo control could have slightly better reliability, linear control und affect with less cost.
Hydraulic systems would have more benefit for human pilot control,
than for autonomous control.

Depending on space und power limitation, und feedback sensing requirement such as: altitude/attitude, velocity of fall rate, control-surface position, proximity, etc...
und the choices for output control such as:
a programmed PLC controlled transducer bank (for an electrical/hydraulic system),
or programmed EPROM controlled servos (for an electrical only system)?

A hydraulic pump motor/reservoir, with electrical pilot-valve controlled, multi-position, hydraulic actuators,
or electrical servo controlled, fast response, linear-positioning, screwed-actuators,
could each have very linear operation, und be used for such fly-by-wire und autonomous requirement. :-)

I worked in the navy on A4 attack aircraft way back when. A system called "Stab Aug" was added as an afterthought during development (early 50's)because it was discovered the airframe tended to vibrate horizontally at high speeds.
So a gyro was added with a hydraulic system attached to the vertically mounted control surface, which worked perfectly.
This shake was so fast it manifested itself as a violent vibration when unchecked.
The moral of the story is Musk can get all the speed response he needs for his spacecraft through hydraulics, without the need for electric motors.Except to drive the hydraulic pumps of course.

20,000 meters is NOT above most of the atmosphere, not even close. There are jets that can fly that high.

The Galactic Explorer got up to roughly 50 km, and that is only half way to "space" which is conventionally defined to start at 100 km.

Lowest Earth orbit is about 160,000 meters with a velocity of roughly 8 km/sec.

The gravity on Kerbel(?) must be much lower than on the Earth, since your orbital velocity was so low.

Your de-orbit and approach technique were terrible, since you did not have the descent profile determined ahead of time. To compensate, you start the descent further away from the target than optimal. If you are going to end up short, you decrease the angle of attack until you are back on the descent path.

Ideally, you would use the almost vertical attitude until below the high heating, then transition to the optimal glide angle to make the ground approach. Yes, even a rocket with no wings can glide. At the correct attitude, you rotate the rocket to tail first and do a burn to scrub off velocity as necessary to make the soft landing - just like the Falcon 9 first stages.

Those flat fins will provide lift, so they are not strictly air brakes. When not at right angles to the flight path, they can actually be used to steer the rocket somewhat.

I was fortunate enough to also see it "in flight" atop a big Boeing as it did a fly by over Moffett Field near my work in Los Altos, CA. Was super exciting. Anyway, I didn't know that every single tile on the shuttle is individually serialized until I saw the shuttle up close. That kinda' threw me for a loop. I took a picture (okay LOTS of pictures) of the underside of the shuttle, which captures every single tile's individual serial number. The shuttle was built on a promise of two week turn around and as time went on, we learned that there was a lot more involved in prepping the orbiters for human flight.    That is the big difference having people on board vs cargo when we talk turnaround.    Shuttle long turnaround was because of the extra care with humans on board.  These were new technologies at the time and we were still learning of the additional stresses on the vehicle which were not completely known. The shuttle was only meant for low orbit and could do things no other vehicle could and still have not done, (launch, retrieve, and repair satellites, major component in the building of ISS, allowed for innovations derived from the shuttle for everyday use and so on).    Were they perfect, no, but in my opinion that were great machines.  Anyone who had a chance to witness a Shuttle launch, knew it was very awe inspiring experience. The example of the B2 using air brakes to yaw is a good one.. but did you know that every modern airliner does the same ? Under 250 knots, say you are doing a left hand turn in an airbus 320.. one would expect the ailerons outboard of the flaps to do most of the work.. however, the left hand spoilers deploy for a few moments on top of the wing to spoil it, and cause it to dip.. while the outboard aileron on the right wing, lifts the wing, this makes for a tighter turn , especially in the pattern, or sharp maneuvers on final.. at high speeds only the ailerons are used, plus a center flaperon that controls roll.. keeps the turns wider and stresses off the air frame.. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q4j2ScNDw8o we can clearly see the 747 pilot doing this just after take off..spoilers deployed .. plus you can see that big flaperon doing it's thing too, between the spoilers.. airplane wings are a work of art.. as for PICA X .. they put together the worlds largest pica x manufacturing plant in 9 months.. , a feat Nasa would take 5 years to do.. says don Rasky .. they can develop, prototype mass produce, and research things with no NASA red tape or political interference.. plus no Lockheed martin, or boeing intentionally running up cost over runs, and ballooning budgets of the gov't run space era.. where initial cost quotes were a joke...f35 is great example of this.. as soon as lockheed got the contract they quadrupled the price of the thing.. standard practice..
Space X has no such luxury, so they innovate and keep costs down.. and they move ahead at amazing speed.. it's not only the tech that makes Space X and Blue Origin viable.. they blasted the old NASA , military culture out of the water.. it was so ossified and in efficient that NASA ground to a halt ..
Rasky Expands on this .. thank goodness Space X came along when they did.. or the USA would be in Space limbo for another Generation like the Obama years.. Pica X .. game changer.. wonder what a 1 inch deep , square foot of the stuff weighs, and what kind of temps it can withstand..

It doesn't matter what anyone thinks Elon's ship (I call it the BFSSS - Big Falcon StarShip System) will do, it only matters what it does. He's building an off-the-shelf plug-it-together-and-go system. According to inside sources, literally everything will be plug-n-play. Bad heat shield? 247 bolts. Pop it off and bolt on a new one. One of the quark-level identical 3D printed engines bad? Six bolts on each feed line, four bolts to hold it in and three electrical umbilical cables to unplug and you can swap it out in two hours even on Mars. His concepts work. Think about it; since perfecting the landing of the F-9 there hasn't been one landing failure. Granted, there were a few crashes in the beginning but once the process was perfected it will stay perfect barring any equipment failures, of course. Having covered, as a reporter, over a hundred shuttle launches at KSC, I can tell you that the STS was the most complicated thing ever made. Not from an engineering standpoint but from a paperwork standpoint. For every hour of actual work on it, there was six hours of paperwork; forms, documentation in triplicate, inspections, inspections of the inspections. I once saw a team of six people spend six hours soldering six wires together. An engineer, his assistant, a solderer and his assistant, a manager and an official inspector discussed each connection for an hour, decided how to do it (do we twist or solder side-by side?), rehearsed it, did it, checked it, measured voltages, inspected it and signed off on it after writing a lengthy description of how they made each connection. Space X would document the process with video, use two guys, one to solder and one to double check, measure the voltage and move on. On that job, SpaceX would save at lease five hours or thirty person-hours. NASA comes up with new ways to weld stuff together. SpaceX comes up with new ways to innovate. NASA says, "We have a tin can with a porta-potty, we can send four people to Mars." That's engineering driving your actions. "Let's send a hundred people at a time to Mars and build a city. All we have to do is figure out how."  That's innovation driving your engineering.  All that is why I say, when NASA finally does land on Mars, Elon will pull up at the Musk Spaceport in his Martian built Tesla Roadster, pick up the four smelly astronauts (porta-potty), drive them on the ElonWay Marspike to the Musk Hilton for a nice shower, and dinner at Marshorn Steakhouse or Marsnara Bread both just a short ride via pressurized tube from the Hilton; proudly displaying on their lawn their logo and corporate slogan via incandescent Mars worms spelling out, "Hilton - Come for a Day, Stay for Six Months, Because You Have To."

So the primary concern for how to drive the fins will be how to store the energy to make them operate.

At hypersonic speeds lift and drag are generated by the same mechanism, impact of gas on the vehicle body (pressure). A lifting trajectory just angles the vehicle enough such that some of the pressure force counteracts gravity in the vehicle frame. A purely ballistic trajectory just uses the pressure to counteract velocity (drag only). Crew vehicles never fly purely ballistic trajectory because of the incredibly high g forces and heat loads. BFS is definitely doing some lifting.

Another essential difference between BFR and the shuttle is the shuttles off-center mounting on the fuel tank. This caused all sorts of problems. The BFR is mounted directly on top of the first stage, which drastically reduces the danger of heat shield damage on launch. The X-20 Dyna-soar would have been mounted like BFR on a Titan rocket. It would have been a much better crew vehicle, but could not have met the military's cargo needs, and was therefore cancelled.

Does anyone know about the mechanical properties of Pica-X? That is, if I were to hold a piece of it in my hands, what would it be like? Would it be semiflexible like a piece of plastic or rubber? Or would it be stiff and crumbly like a foam? This sort of thing makes a huge difference in how easy it is to handle and apply to the spaceship, as well as in what ways it can be damaged and how visible such damage is.

For instance, the shuttle's tiles would be some sort of low density porous ceramic, and as such high fragility is expected. Worse, a brittle material tends to crack and shatter, and visually inspecting such a material for hairline cracks is difficult.

Another huge issue is how hard it is to remove the tiles, and also whether you have to replace single damaged tiles, or if they wear uniformly without mechanical damage, allowing you to replace them all at once. With the shuttle, I can't help but imagine someone with a hammer and chisel carefully digging out a bad tile, and then scraping off the adhesive, all the while having to be very careful not to damage adjacent tiles. In this way, being able to replace them all at once would help all by itself since it's easier to remove them if you don't have to worry so much about damaging other tiles in the process.

The last issue is how easy it is to machine the tiles. There's a huge range in difficulty here, and I rather suspect that the shuttle tiles are made of one of the more difficult materials to work with. One other huge advantage not related to material for the BFS has over the shuttle simply has to do with modern computer controlled milling systems. It's pretty easy to imagine putting a Pica-X blank into the milling machine, punching in a request for tile D176, and in 30 minutes you have a freshly milled tile of the specific shape you need. Back in the 80's and 90's, the machinery was a lot more primitive, requiring much more manual control. A related issue is what sort of post processing is needed after milling. Do you have to do special treatments and such in the factory, or can you literally just have a milling machine sitting at the end of the refurbishment building?

I think BFS will fail. The particulars are coming along nicely but Mr. Musk is missing the big picture. He is making the same mistake we made with the Shuttle; His grand strategy is wrong.

The people and the stuff require different safety levels. People should go up and come down in spacecraft that are as small and safe as possible. Assume that from time to time a spacecraft will kill its crew. You want it to kill 3 or 4 people, not 7 or 20. The engineering for smaller craft is orders of magnitude less complex than for big reentry vehicles; the safety of small craft is orders of magnitude better.

I remember the Economist magazine made fun of a Soviet made car brand by calling it "Mir on Earth." We used to make fun of the Soviet's backwardness, their engineering inferiority. But they got the strategy right. We killed 14 astronauts, the Soviets have killed 4 . . . and no one since 1971.

Same idea if you're going to the moon or mars. Send the people and the stuff separately, at different speeds (and most importantly) with different levels of safety. If you want to have a command module big enough so people don't go nuts (or absorb too much radiation) over 300 days to Mars, then build a big ship for space and have a small re-entry vehicle to deliver them to pre-built facilities on the planet.

For mars the time difference is also important. Time to mars depends on how much fuel you want to burn. Send the stuff on a slow, year-long trip. Get the people there in 4 or 5 months.

The most glaring difference between this and the space shuttle is how it launches. While the shuttle was attached to the side of a massive fuel tank, the BFS will sit well above it ensuring far more safety in case the main rocket has a failure. If the shuttle had launched like the BFS will, there's a good chance no losses would have ever occurred.

Considering that they are using physics to guide their design process, it isn't too surprising that there are some similarities between the BFS and Space Shuttle considering that both have been designed to do some pretty similar things.

The most staggering thing about F9/FH to BFR/BFS transition is that there's very little evolution. It's revolution but using all the lessons learnt.
I'm wondering about the hydraulics vs motor. Hydraulics uses powerful motors to move fluids into linear actuators. Size differences change the pressure and the work done between the compressor and the actuator. A motor would presumably be heavily geared instead. The transition to linear actuation is trivial. Or the rotary action could be used directly to the hinge shaft of the fins. Either way, you need electrical energy that will presumably come from a small propellant burner and electrical turbine unit. The control of that much electrical power is going to need some very heavy duty power electronics. But like you say, Tesla would have the answers.
The best bit of all about BFS in all its iterations is the very low re-entry dV (from earth orbit) and extremely low landing dV (lower than the F9 boosters).

Basically, any craft flying people through space could be a “space shuttle”, the BFR to me looks like it could be classified as the shuttle done right. However, as you said the mechanics of re-entry and landing are completely different.  Just the general design has similarities. Using large surface areas to scrub off speed during re-entry just works, plus it requires zero fuel to accomplish. The shuttles main engines only managed to scrub about 1% of the speed off (thanks to a highly intelligent everyday astronaut guy for that info) and the body did the rest, just as the Apollo missions used the capsules entering bottom first to do so. So far the BFR seems to be evolving to take lessons learned from the F9 landings and previous space mission to evolve a craft that will be the most capable space craft ever designed.
